In the First Judcial Circuit of South Dakota Judge Arthur Rusch put a person on probation in 2000 for passing checks against a non existant account.
 
 While on porbation this person wrote +$40,000 worth of no account checks.
 The person used made up social security numbers, drivers license numbers,addresses, and birthdays to bypass check scanners.
 
 The person wrote so many bad checks the Judge took the person off probation early. Judges Rusch, Eng and Anderson all know of the bad checks and say it is ok for this party to do it.
 In fact the South Dakota Supreme Court said it was all right for this person to do it. Mommy works for South Dakota corrections and that would not do to put this person in prison.
 
 The Attoreny General of South Dakota also knows and says it is not his jurisdiciton. The Judges do not have to obey the law. emoticon_xbouncer

Something sounds a little strange about this ruling.
It seems obvious that some part of the story is missing here.

The FBI in Sioux Falls, South Dakota investigated the above matter.
 The person while on probation wrote over 200,000 dollars in bad checks using ficticious social security numbers. This was a 10 different banks in 2 states.
 The matter has been turned over to the u.s. attorney general for prosecution.
 Why the Judges do not follow the law is a secret.
 
 
 
 If you doubt call the sioux falls branch of the fbi and ask for agent matt miller

 This obviously does not apply to South Dakota.
 
 The First Amendment protects anonymous speech both in our society at large and on the Internet specifically. As described in the Supreme Court's anonymous speech case, McIntyre v. Ohio Elections Commission, 514 U.S. 334 (1995), the United States has a strong tradition of anonymous speech in both literary and political contexts. (3)For example, the Court notes that "American names such as Mark Twain (Samuel Langhorne Clemens) and O. Henry (William Sydney Porter) come readily to mind. Benjamin Franklin employed numerous different pseudonyms." 514 U.S. at 341, n. 4. Politically, "[t]hat tradition is most famously embodied in the Federalist Papers, authored by James Madison, Alexander Hamilton, and John Jay, but signed 'Publius.' Publius' opponents, the Anti-Federalists, also tended to publish under pseudonyms: prominent among them were 'Cato,' believed to be New York Governor George Clinton; 'Centinel,' probably Samuel Bryan or his father, Pennsylvania judge and legislator George Bryan," among others. And ultimately, "[a] forerunner of all of these writers was the pre-Revolutionary War English pamphleteer, 'Junius,' whose true identity remains a mystery." 514 U.S. at 343, n. 6. emoticon_ic
